learning_outcomes.description: demonstrate advanced skills in textual analysis
display a knowledge of postmodern fictional texts and of theorisations of postmodern culture
show a critical perspective on these theories and narratives
consider what these aspects of fiction and theory say about contemporary Western culture
demonstrate advanced research and writing skills

assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
There are ten tutorials in the semester, beginning in week two. See the marking schema below for full requirements.


Please note: students are NOT able to apply for an extension via the Unitask portal for this assessment item. Please contact your tutor/course coordinator directly to see if alternative arrangements are available.


Criteria & Marking:

To gain the mark for each week students are required to do all of the following:

  1. arrive on time and stay for the entirety of the tutorial.
  2. bring copies (preferably print) of the novel and theoretical reading for that week. These will be checked.
  3. complete a writing task before your tutorial that covers the week's required readings. The writing task question will be made available on Blackboard at the relevant week's Learning Resources folder at 9am on the Friday of the week before the relevant tutorial. Your response should be submitted via the link in the week's "Resources" folder on Blackboard before your tutorial.
  4. Your response will be assessed on a pass/fail basis. Responses that fail will be contacted by your tutor to check in with your progress in the course. Your response should be  80-120 words.

If one or more of these elements are not satisfactory, no marks are awarded for that week's tutorial.

 

If a student is absent from a tutorial they must notify their tutor before class, and then they can complete a catch up worksheet to gain the mark. This worksheet must be returned by the following week's seminar. You are only allowed two worksheets for the semester. You do not need to provide any documentation for your absence.

You must gain the weekly mark for 5 seminars, otherwise you will receive a mark of zero for this assessment item.

Marking Allocation:

  • 0-4 seminars passed in designated weeks 2-12: 0 marks.
  • 5 seminars passed in designated weeks 2-12: 5 marks.
  • 6 seminars passed in designated weeks 2-12: 6 marks
  • 7 seminars passed in designated weeks 2-12: 7 marks.
  • 8 seminars passed in designated weeks 2-12: 8 marks.
  • 9 seminars passed in designated weeks 2-12: 9 marks.
  • 10 seminars passed in designated weeks 2-12: 15 marks


This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit via the link in the week's "Resources" folder on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
The Research Essay requires you to develop a sustained, comparative argument about two primary texts from the first part of the course. You will choose one of the set essay questions provided and craft a thesis-driven response that demonstrates detailed textual analysis, awareness of relevant theoretical frameworks, and engagement with scholarly research.


Your essay should integrate close reading with critical analyses of the formal, thematic, and cultural concerns of postmodern literature as they appear in your chosen texts. You must consult and correctly reference a minimum of six scholarly sources. Conventional essay style is required: an introduction with a clear thesis, logically organised body paragraphs, and a conclusion.


Length: 2200 words (+/-10%, including quotations)


Eligible Texts: Any two of the following primary texts: White Noise, American Psycho, If on a Winter’s Night a Traveller, Nights at the Circus, Blood and Guts in High School.


Rationale: This task evaluates your ability to develop an extended comparative argument, perform detailed close reading, engage critically with secondary scholarship, and apply theoretical concepts to literary texts. It allows you to practise sustained research-based analysis in preparation for the interpretive skills required in the final exam.


Use of Generative AI/MT: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. While students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final exam assesses your ability to perform close reading, apply conceptual frameworks, and synthesise ideas from the final section of the course. The exam consists of three short essay responses, each worth 10%, based on passages provided from three of the following texts: Vineland, Shame, Landscape for a Good Woman, The Passion


For each response, you will be given a passage and a critical question. You must analyse how the passage engages with central concerns of the text—such as history, memory, subjectivity, political power, narrative authority, or postmodern strategies of representation—and situate your reading within the broader thematic and formal concerns of the work.


Length: Approximately 500 words per response


Format: 2-hour exam (+10 minutes perusal time)


Rationale: This exam provides an opportunity to demonstrate interpretive precision, conceptual understanding, and comparative insight under timed conditions. It assesses your ability to read closely, think critically and independently, and apply theoretical knowledge to textual analysis without reliance on external resources.


Use of Generative AI/MT: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
